rdf:Description.skos:definition: A statistical model in which some of the parameters of the original model have been removed.
A term coined by the American sociologist, Harold Garfinkel, ethnomethodology investigates the constitutive organisation of social interaction.

A method of collecting observational data through the use of pre-coded schedules which allow the presence, frequency, and duration of prespecified actions, behaviours, or occurences to be recorded in a systematic way.
A type of applied research designed to find the most effective way to bring about a desired social change or to solve a practical problem, usually in collaboration with those being researched.
An investigative strategy in which the researcher's professional identity and academic intentions are hidden, either partially or fully, from those involved in the study
The methods, procedures and practices that surround the use of visual media and technologies in the research process.

Ethnography involves the production of highly detailed accounts of how people in a social setting lead their lives, based on systematic and long-term observation of, and discussion with, those within the setting.
A term with a variety of meanings and historical resonances but which today usually refers to the intensive study of a small number of cases, or a single case.
The extent to which an instrument for measuring something gives consistent results.
The extent to which something that has been studied can be said to have been accurately depicted.
Broadly speaking, the statistical assessment of empirically observed sample data against a theoretical model that asserts what would be found under particular specified conditions.
A computer program for analysing structural equation models. LISREL stands for 'Linear Structural Relations'.
Any of several methods for examining multiple (three or more) variables at the same time—usually two or more independent variables and one dependent variable.

Latent variable models concern the presence, definition, and/or influence of constructs that either cannot be observed or characteristics that are, in principle, observable but that have not been directly observed in a given dataset.
A form of factor analysis conducted to test hypotheses about the factors one would expect to find.
A confirmatory, multivariate technique that examines the causal relationships between variables in a diagrammatic form.
A characteristic of a population described by a statistic.
The application of mathematical principles to the measurement of psychological constructs.
An intelligence test is a structured situation designed to elicit information about the cognitive abilities of an individual.
Using statistical tests to determine how likely it is that the observed characteristics of a sample have occurred by chance.
A term used to describe the situation where a value or measure of a variable is larger or smaller than would be expected from chance alone.
A form of group interview centred on a particular topic or activity and in which the interaction within the group is used to facilitate the elicitation of participants' views.
The interactive patterns and processes operating within a small group.

A set of procedures used to simplify a complex set of quantitative data by analysing the correlations between variables in order to uncover a small number of factors which can express what is comment to the variables and their associated correlations.
A form of observation in which the observer minimises interaction with those present in the setting.

A term with many meanings but broadly speaking the notion of reflexivity refers to the researcher's engaging in processes of self-awareness and self-criticism as an intrinsic feature of the research process.
Approaches to research in which the researcher observes research participants in some way. The extent to which the presence of the researcher is apparent to those being studied can vary.
A methodological approach in which, usually over a lengthy period, a researcher becomes involved, either overtly or covertly, in a setting, culture, group or organisation in order to study it.

Many statistical procedures depend on the assumption that modelling errors are independent of one other. In the context of time-series research designs where, for example, repeated observations are made of the same entity such as an individual or country, this assumption is often not met. Where this occurs the errors are said to autocorrelated.

An approach associated with the American statistician John Tukey, exploratory data analysis attempts to examine and display observed data in relatively straightforward ways which do not require the imposition of a prior model or hypothesis.
Usually, the difference between observed and expected values based on an estimated model of some kind.
The total set of something that is or has been studied. The term can refer to any set of entities not just all the people who live in a particular country.
A range of values so defined that one can specify the probability that the value of a population parameter lies within it.

A term used to describe the shape of the normal distribution when the values of that distribution are plotted against the frequency of their occurrence. The bell curve is a symmetric distribution with the highest frequencies clustered around the mid-point and with the tails falling off evenly to infinity on either side.
A number indicating the values of a dependent variable associated with the values of an independent variable or variables.
A term which covers a range of techniques for explaining the variability in a dependent variable based on the values of one or more independent variables.

A computer-based approach to statistical inference which uses the variability within a sample to estimate empirically the sampling distribution. In practice, bootstrapping involves randomly resampling with replacement from the sample over many iterations in a way that mimics the original sampling scheme.
A measure of the spread in a distribution derived from the sum of the squared deviations from the mean of the distribution divided by the number of cases in the distribution.

A method for estimating standard errors and confidence intervals by taking repeated random subsamples, without replacement, from an original sample, eliminating one or more data observations on each occasion.
A measure of the accuracy of a sample estimate. The standard error is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of a statistic.
A method used for estimating the population parameters most likely to have resulted in observed sample data.
Broadly speaking, a numerical representation of how likely it that certain observations will occur.

It is common in the social sciences to study populations which are themselves embedded within other populations, for example pupils, classrooms, schools. Multilevel analysis is a statistical approach which allows the simultaneous modelling of processes across such different units of analysis.
The frequency distribution of possible values for a statistic over all possible samples under the sampling design.

Sampling is the process of selecting a given number of units of analysis from a population. Although in social research these units are often individuals, they do not need to be but could be households, firms, countries, or whatever. Sampling is often based on randomness to ensure representativeness, although non-random sampling might be used in some circumstances.
When examining the relationship between two variables, the assertion that the independent variable has no effect on the dependent variable or that there is no association between the two variables.
The number of subjects or cases selected for inclusion in a sample.
A variable explaining another (dependent) variable.

A term with no precise equivalent in English, it refers to a form of human action concerned with what is right and good in a given situation, and the competence, sensibility, and sensitivity required to make such judgements.
The extent to which there are random variations in the accuracy of a set of observations.

Data quality refers to the data’s suitability to serve its purpose in a given context, considering such things as relevance and reliability. Data management is the process of controlling and organising data generated from a research project.
The process by which a (usually numerical) value is assigned the level or state of some entity.
Inaccuracy that arises due to flaws in a measuring instrument or from the mistakes of those who use it.

A term with many meanings, poststructuralism is an intellectual movement that emerged in France in the 1960s. Poststructualism is characterised by a set of practices based around notions such as the decentering of the self, pantextualism (the notion that everything can be thought of as a text), intertextuality, and deconstructionism.

In contrast to traditional notions privileging the researcher as the source of authoritative pronouncements, a concept implying that the world is characterised by a plurality of voices worthy of being heard.
Approaches to evaluation based on the use of qualitative methods.
The systematic determination of the value, validity, or effectiveness of something; often in terms of some kind of intervention.
A study designed to assess the effectiveness of some means for improving a particular situation.

Sources of data not involving the direct elicitation of responses from research subjects. Unobtrusive measures, which can be derived from sources such as traces, non-participant observation, and records of various kinds avoid problems that arise from people being aware that they are being studied.
A term with many meanings but broadly speaking a set of interrelated ideas or concepts relevant to the explanation or interpretation of a particular topic or domain.
The body of theory originally developed by Sigmund Freud and his followers that underpins the practice of psychoanalysis.

An approach to action research which aims to transcend the boundaries between research and activism in order to produce knowledge and action that is directly useful to people, and to empower people through the process of constructing and using their own knowledge.

A body of thought centred on the work of Karl Marx which provides an analysis and critique of capitalist society based on a commitment to the materialist conception of history and the application of dialectics as a methodological strategy.
A method of interviewing in which photographs are used to bring forth understandings and interpretations of what is being depicted in the photograph.
An approach to studying the past in which recorded interviews are used to capture the memories of those who have experienced particular events or conditions.
An approach focused on the interpretation of narratives or stories generated by those participating in a research project, and the analytic procedures associated with such an approach.
Collecting, preserving and interpreting the experiences, voices and memories of people and communities in past events through using interview methods.

Approaches to the interpretation and understanding of material arising from the use of qualitative methods, such as transcripts from depth interviews and focus groups, fieldnotes from participant observation studies, and so on
Research in which data are collected using video technologies.
An approach that uses a form of individual interview directed to documenting the respondent's life, or an aspect of it that has developed over the life course.
Research, whether by historians or not, which utilises the sources, methods, and techniques typically used by historians.
The analysis of changes in variables over time. Also used to refer to the statistical procedures associated with such analysis.
A variable explained by one or more other (independent) variables.

In its simplest form a dummy variable is a dichotomous categorical variable in which one value is coded "1" and the other "0". This allows the variable to be treated as a continuous variable for certain kinds of statistical analysis.
Approaches to the design of experiments that are allow causal inferences to be made despite the absence of procedures for randomly allocating research subjects to experimental conditions.
In experimental research, a group that, for the sake of comparison, does not receive the treatment the experimenter is interested in studying.

Experiments are ways of assessing causal relationships by, in its simplest form, randomly allocating 'subjects' to two groups and then comparing one (the 'control group') in which no changes are made, with the other (the 'test group') who are subjected to some manipulation or stimulus.
In experimental research, the group that receives the treatment the experimenter is interested in studying.

A form of inquiry in which researchers use their own experiences to develop understandings and insights into a culture, subculture, or life experience. As a method it combines features of life history and ethnographic methods.
A statistical method analysing the linear relationship between an interval level dependent variable and two or more independent variables.
A set of attributes for some entity that can vary in some way.
A method focused on the classification of entities based on characteristics that distinguish a given entity from other entities.
The framework that has been created to seek answers to research questions
Research that looks for patterns, ideas, or hypotheses, rather than research that tries to test or confirm hypotheses.

Information not available for a particular case although other data relevant to the case are available. An example of missing data would be where a respondent has, for whatever reason, not provided an answer to a survey question.
A method for determining a regression equation. It minimises the sum of squares of the residuals, that is the vertical distances between observed data and those predicted by the linear model.
Research focused on the elicitation and interpretation of people's narrative accounts of their experience.

Also referred to as a standardised interview, a structured interview is one in which the interview questions together with relevant response categories are prespecified on a questionnaire. In the interview the interviewer is expected to adhere closely to the wording and order of the questions set out in the questionnaire.

Although the term can have several slightly different meanings, it generally refers to a research method that involves asking a sample of people a set of pre-prepared questions on a single occasion in order to gather data about their opinions and behaviour.
An approach to research heavily focused on documenting individual biographies.
The processes involved in capturing unstructured data through (usually lengthy) processes of interviewing or observation.
Interviews are conversations designed to elicit information about some relevant topic. Interviews vary in the extent to which the process of elicitation is loosely or tightly structured.
A literature review is a descriptive and/or analytic summary of the existing material relating to some topic or area of study. The term also refers to the process of producing such a review.
A critique is a critical analysis or evaluation of something such as a topic, area of study, or a literary or artistic production.

In general, a family of statistical methods that deal with the differences in the means of a variable across groups of observations. More specifically, a statistical procedure used to test for the difference between two sample means in situations where the dependent variable is continuous and the independent variables are categorical.
Approaches to the interpretation and understanding of numerical data produced from methods such as survey research.
Specialised suites of software programs, such as SPSS, used for conducting data analysis..
Inquiry that combines two or more methods. This particular term usually refers to mixing that crosses the quantitative-qualitative boundary.

A stance towards methodological issues and problems that advocates a flexible approach to the selection of research methods, on the principle that it is the nature of the problem being researched that best dictates the most appropriate means for studying it.
An approach propounded by Karl Marx which sees the development of human society as grounded in the ways in which human beings produce the material conditions of life.

A mathematical theory of competitive games in which each player wants to figure out the best way to play games given their rules. The games in question have to be strategic games, that is, not games of pure chance, but games based on knowledge, including knowledge of what the other players are likely to know.
The crossing of traditional academic boundaries.
A theory about the nature of being and existence. In computing, the formal representation of knowledge as a set of concepts within a particular domain.

A term itself resisting brief definition, it is used across many different fields and disciplines to refer to a style of work that emphasises the fragmentation and instability of meaning, and the reflexive deconstruction of knowledge, rationality, social institutions, and language.

Those intellectual approaches, usually associated with the qualitative research tradition, that assume the meaning of human action inheres in that action, and that the researcher's task is to explicate that meaning.
Approaches that avoid prior manipulation of the study setting by the researcher or the placing of constraints on the possible outcomes of a study.
A form of that uses a multivariate contingency table to examine the relationship between categorical variables.
A statistical method which evaluates mean differences on two or more dependent criterion variables simultaneously.
A statistical procedure relating a continuous dependent variable with two or more independent variables at least one of which is categorical and another is continuous.

A form of multivariate regression analysis in which the causal relations between variables are represented by means of a flow diagram and in which path coefficients estimate the strength of the relationship between two variables when all the other variables are held constant.
Interviews conducted remotely using e-mail, videoconferencing and so on.
The rules for adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing matrices.

Associated with the work of the American sociologists George Herbert Mead and Herbert Blumer, symbolic interactionism is a theoretical and methodological approach which stresses the importance of understanding the ways in which meaning emerges out of social interaction.

Those scholars and their students in the Department of Sociology at the University of Chicago in the period between the two world wars whose work is seen (sometimes in mythologised ways) as foundational for the development of qualitative methods. A postwar group at Chicago influenced by this tradition is sometimes referred to as the 'second Chicago school'.

In qualitative research, a procedure by which raw data, often but not always in the form of elicited speech which has been recorded in some way, are transformed into meaningful and theoretically meaningful categories. In quantitative research, the process of categorising data from open-ended questions.

A term in grounded theory that refers to the use as a conceptual category of a word or phrase used by research participants which seems in itself to express the meaning of that category in a pithy or memorable way.

A situation in which there are considerably unequal variances in the dependent variable for the same values of the independent variable in the different populations being sampled and compared in a regression analysis or an ANOVA.

In multiple regression multicollinearity is said to exist when two or more of the independent variables are themselves highly correlated, a situation that makes it difficult to establish the effect each has on the dependent variable.
A philosophical doctrine based on the view that reasoning is the main way in which humans attain knowledge.
An approach that proceeds from the assumption that individuals balance costs and benefits in making decisions.
The use of qualitative approaches to examine those activities that are mediated by information and communication technologies such as the Internet.
The right someone has to control access to their person and to their personal information.
A survey delivered over the Internet, sometimes by e-mail but usually via the World Wide Web.

The ethical principle and requirement that those participating in a research study have the right to know that they are being researched, to be told fully about the purposes of the research and its potential risks and benefits, and that they can withdraw their participation at any time.
The use of the Internet to conduct primary or secondary research.
A research strategy involving comparison across two or more nation states.

Data mining refers to the process of discovering useful patterns in very large databases. It uses methods from statistics, machine learning, and database management to restructure and analyze data in ways that permit knowledge or information to be extracted from the material.

A systematic review is a review of the literature that is conducted in a methodical manner based on a prespecified protocol and with the aim of synthesising the retrieved information often by means of a meta-analysis.
The analysis of pre-existing data in social research.
A standardised coefficient showing the strength of the relationship between two variables when all the other variables are held constant.

The process of rendering into textual form material that was originally produced in another medium, for example by typing up the content of a recorded interview. Often the analyst makes a conscious decision on theoretical grounds about the amount of detail to be included.
A picture or likeness, generally made using a camera
The social and communicative processes by which people act towards others and react to others' actions towards them.

An approach to social practice associated with the work of the management theorist Chris Argyis and others that links meaning-making by human beings to the exploration of causal theories shaping the social world.
A correction made when calculating the chi-squared statistic in order to improve its accuracy for 2x2 tables, especially those in which cell values are small.
A type of regression analysis in which the dependent variable is dichotomous.

A statistical test to establish whether there is association between two nominal or ordinal level variables. The test compares observed frequencies with the frequencies that would be expected if there was no association between the variables.
Statistical data analysis directed toward data measured at the nominal or ordinal level.

Research aimed at identifying similarities and differences between social entities. While the term is sometimes widened to include comparisons between many different types of entity, it often refers to research comparing nation states, societies, or cultures.
The process and procedures used in order to find relevant material within the research literature associated with a particular topic.
A research method in which findings from individual studies in a target area are formally combined for the purpose of integrating, synthesizing, and making sense of them.
An alternative to ordinary least-squares regression models used with data having nested categories or levels.

A form of analysis often applied to textual material that is devoted to the interpretation and understanding of social actions and events referred to by relating them to their wider discursive contexts.
Broadly speaking, the philosophical view that objects exist independently of the mind.
The social study of language as used in talk, text and other forms of communication.

A term with somewhat different meanings in different disciplines, structuralism broadly speaking refers to an approach concerned with identifying and describing those features of the social world that cannot be observed but must be inferred.
The branch of philosophy concerned with the nature of knowledge and its justification.
A philosophical doctrine which holds that there are no universal truths or absolute principles.

An approach to discourse analysis, politically committed to social change in favour of oppressed social groups, that aims to explicate the role of discursive practice in producing and maintaining unequal power relations.
Using methodology in a creative and dynamic manner that differs from the research currently available within the field.

An approach to understanding in the natural and social sciences that regards the objects of scientific knowledge as existing and acting independently of our beliefs about them. In the social sciences, however, the approach often involves a normatively critical orientation to existing social forms.

A radical tradition of politically engaged analysis often associated with the Frankfurt School and its followers, a group of neo-Marxist thinkers originally based at the Institute for Social Reseach at the University of Frankfurt-am-Main, many of whom later fled Nazi Germany and settled in the United States.
Research undertaken with the intention of applying the results to a specific problem.
Examining and evaluating different aspects of education and learning processes, through the individuals, organizations, and institutions that play a role in shaping educational outcomes.
A form of interviewing based on respectful, on-going relationships with interviewees that allows for extensive and meaningful understanding of their understanding of the world.
Arbitrary values used in hypothesis testing to delimitate two regions; one in which the analyst rejects the null hypothesis and another in which the hypothesis cannot be rejected.
Quantitative mechanisms to determine whether there is enough evidence to "reject" a null hypothesis about a process.

Often referred to as market research in Britain, marketing research involves the collection, analysis and use of information about customers and consumers and is used by firms and organisations to make decisions about the provision of their products and services.
The study of a cohort (a set of individuals who have experienced a particular event at the same time) over an extended period.
The extent to which members of a cohort share experiences as a result of that membership. Researchers often wish to distinguish such effects from those due to ageing or historical period.
The analysis of data produced by making repeated measures of the same variables across a (usually lengthy) series of time points.

An approach developed by the American sociologists Barney Glaser and Anselm Strauss, grounded theory builds systematic theoretical statements inductively from the coding and analysis of observational data, and the subsequent development and refinement of conceptual categories which are tested and re-tested in further data collection. Subsequently, Glaser and Strauss diverged in their understanding of the method.

A term that refers to a variety of methods for analysing text usually in a quantitative way that involves counting, coding comparing, contrasting, and categorizing the elements (most typically words) forming a corpus of textual data. Sometimes also used, probably inappropriately, to refer to the qualitative analysis of text.
A theoretical and/or socio-political movement analysing and challenging the systematic unequal treatment of women.

A growing movement in qualitative research, particularly in applied fields such as education and health, which seeks to draw on and integrate into research practice work traditionally associated with the arts including but not restricted to poetry, drama, dance, music, and visual expression.
A test that provides an indication of how close the relationship is between data actually obtained and the theoretical distribution of the data based on the null hypothesis.
Pilot studies are small scale studies usually intended to develop or try out research instruments or to assess the feasibility of a larger scale study.
The degree to which something, such as a particular research study, is capable of being accomplished.

A list of questions with associated instructions and response categories (which can include space to record verbatim answers where necessary) used by an interviewer to conduct an interview. Interview schedules are commonly, but not exclusively, used in survey research.
An interview in which some combination of open and closed questions is used. The ratio of open to closed questions depends on the degree of structuring involved.
The person who elicits and manages discussion in a focus group. In online environments, the person who has been allocated responsibility for ensuring that discussions remain within acceptable bounds.
The mean (average) of a set of scores in matrix algebra.
Broadly speaking an activity by which items of data are allocated in an exhaustive and mutually exclusive way to a place within a wider systematically-organised schema.

A method of statistical inference named after Thomas Bayes, an 18th-century English mathematician. The method involves working backwards from effect to cause, by estimating the conditional probability of a cause given that certain events have occurred. Bayesian inference involves using new information, called the posterior probability, to revise earlier estimates of probability, called prior probability.
A method for evaluating the conditional probability of an event, particularly an unknown prior event, given that a known subsequent event has occurred.
Methods aimed at capturing experiences that take place 'on the move'. Also, methods utilising new information and communication technologies such as mobile phones to capture data.
The ability of a statistical test to detect effects of a specific size.

The process of breaking apart. In the social sciences often refers to the proliferation of sub-disciplines and specialisms within a particular area. In qualitative research can refer to the extent to an analysis decontextualises the data.
Techniques for exploring and identifying problems in a situation. In statistics can refer to methods for establishing how far the assumptions behind a particular procedure have been met.
An methodological approach to research in communities that emphasizes participation and action. It seeks to understand the world by trying to change it, collaboratively and following reflection.
An approach to modelling change occurring over time.
Latent variables are variable that are not directly observed in data. Instead they are inferred from observed variables through the application of a mathematical model of some kind.

Canonical correlation involves the correlation between one set of X variables and another set of Y variables, using not the variables actually recorded in the data but abstract variables ('latent variables') that underlie a given set of variables. It follows that there may be several latent variables in any set of variables as well as a number of coefficients.
A measure of covariation, or linear relationship, between two variables expressed in the original units of measurement.
Variables located inside other variables as when, for example, local unemployment rates are nested within regional and national data.

The information produced by governments through the regular enumeration of their country's population. Censuses typically produce aggregate data but disaggreated 'microdata' might be made available to researchers under certain restrictive conditions typically relating to the anonymity of those enumerated.
The primary ideas and techniques of research.
In Bayesian inference, the researcher's opinion stated as a probability before the study begins.
The process of controlling and organising the information generated from a research project.
Broadly speaking, shifts in the nature of society, social institutions, social relations, and social behaviour over time.
An approach to discourse inspired by the philosopher Michel Foucault that focuses on the material practice though which being is rendered thinkable, manageable and governable.
A form of discourse analysis which focuses on how people use psychological categories and constructions in everyday and institutional settings.

A term with several meanings. It can refer to the collapsing of data into fewer, broader categories, or the providing of upper and lower limits for a quantity. In qualitative research, bracketing refers to the practice of considering something apart from its context.
A model for the analysis of time-series data which includes an autoregressive element based on a weighted average of past values, a moving average term, and the number of differencing passes.

An approach originally developed in Science and Technology Studies, ANT seeks to explore the processes by which actors through a variety of processes come to form activity networks of various kinds. Actors in this context are understood as social, conceptual, textual, and/or technical entities, a stance which permits the assigning of agency to non-humans.
An ordered sequence of elements from a set. More generally the various ways is which a set can be ordered.
Aspects of subjects’ “backgrounds” that may influence other variables, but will not be influenced by them. Often demographic characteristics.
A measure of the association between two dichotomous variables that is based on the chi-squared statistic.
Functionalist theories or models aim to explain human behavior by reference to the the functions they are said to perform for a particular group, society, culture, or community.

A term coined by the sociologist Jack Douglas to refer to a style of qualitative interviewing that tries to work with rather than against the communicative processes occuring in the interview situation.

A term coined by the American sociologists James A. Holstein and Jaber F. Gubrium to refer to a social constructivist perspective on interviewing that stresses the interview as a collaborative site for reality-construction and meaning-making.

The term refers to a range of multivariate statistical procedures used to determine whether some set of entities of interest to the researcher, such as individuals, responses, or cases, are similar enough to be grouped together into clusters. While the entities within the cluster are similar to one another, the clusters themselves are dissimilar.
An organised, often digital collection of data. Also refers to computer packages for storing, managing, and analysing data.
In a panel study data are collected from a sample using successive waves of data collection with the aim of studying change over time.

Data from a study in which a group of people is followed over time from a common starting point. At each time period data are collected relevant to that specific period thus obviating the problems that arise from retrospective reporting of past events.

Although the term is used somewhat differently in different disciplines, it generally refers to research involving data collected at more than one point in time and focused on the measurement and analysis of change over time in the units of study.
Data generated by respondents thinking back to past occasions or states.
Statistical tests that do not rely on data conforming to a particular distribution.
A square matrix formed of the covariances of variables.
The statistical association between two variables measured at ordinal, interval or ratio level. Many different 'correlation co-efficients' are used as measures of association.
A set of statistical techniques used when data have certain characteristics such as an approximation to the normal distribution and measurement at interval or ratio level.
A class of statistical models that analyse observed frequencies in a cross-classified table in order to measure the strength of the association between two or more ordered categorical variables.
A class of multivariate statistical procedures used when the dependent variable is a qualitative measure rather than a continuous one.

Measures of association refer to a wide variety of coefficients that measure the statistical strength of the relationship on the variables of interest. These measures of association, are described in several ways, depending on the analysis.
A measure of association describing a ratio of one odds to another.
In grounded theory memos are brief notes designed to capture emerging information.
A procedure in the grounded theory approach to qualitative data analysis in which each finding and interpretation that emerges from the data is compared with existing codes and categories.
A form of non-probability sampling in which the researcher seeks out by various means sample members having characteristics relevant to the topic under study.

A term associated with grounded theory, theoretical sampling refers to the process of selecting additional sample elements on the basis of their potential for confirming or disconfirming emerging theoretical formulations.
Sometimes used to refer to epistemological positions that are explicitly non-positivist, but the term is also used to describe contemporary less strict and more 'moderate' forms of positivism.

A constant, systematic form or source of error in research arising either from the researcher's conscious or unconscious predelictions or from features of the context within which the research is produced that tend to predetermine research findings.
The extent to which you can come to conclusions about one thing (often a population) based on information about another (often a sample).

A somewhat contested notion, causation refers to a mode of explanation in the social sciences which examines the relationships between cause and effect in a set of variables. A relationship between independent and dependent variables is deemed to be causal when, having ruled out other spurious factors, the variables consistently covary in a time-ordered way.

A rather contested term with a number of different meanings. It refers very broadly to view that it is possible and desirable to apply to the study of social life the methods, concepts and procedures of the natural sciences.
Short for probability value, that is, the probability that a statistic could occur by sampling error—if the null hypothesis is true.
A statistical procedure designed to assess whether differences in the means of two groups reflect differences in their respective populations or are simply due to chance.
A measure of the internal reliability or consistency of the items in an instrument or index.
A process of reasoning that moves from general principles to conclusions about particular instances.
Broadly a measure of the association or strength between two variables often used to describe the magnitude of a treatment effect.
Broadly speaking, what it is that the researcher wishes to find out. Such questions are often framed in ways that point to what the researcher has to do in order for them to be answered.
The process of gathering and measuring information on variables of interest, often through methods such as interviews and surveys.
The processes involved in capturing structured data through the use of instruments such as questionnaires.
The percentage or proportion of members of a sample who respond to a questionnaire.
When an eligible sample member fails to respond to all, or some, items.

Behaviourism is an approach in psychology in which human behaviour is explained by reference to observable and measurable responses to environmental stimuli. Behaviours, from this point of view, can be studied without needing to posit the presence of internal physiological states or hypothetical entities such as the mind.
A detailed description of the nature of the proposed research, its significance and how it will be conducted.
The process of applying for research funding through institutions such as a government departments, corporations, foundations or trusts.

The process of analysing a text in which the meaning of the text as a totality is derived from the understanding of its individual parts, while at the same time the meaning of the individual parts is derived from an understanding of the totality.
In statistical hypothesis testing the error that results from rejecting a null hypothesis that is true.
The branch of statistics which deals with generalization from samples to population parameters.
A measure of association used with two variable contingency tables. In two-by-two tables Cramer's V has the same value as the measure of association known as phi.
A term used in different ways but often referring to a principle that research be conducted in ways that minimise the role of personal or idiosyncratic factors.
A term with a number of different meanings but often used in the social sciences to refer to the belief in the possibility of objective science.
Nodes are the elements of a network that are connected to one another.
An approach focusing on the patterns of relationships between individuals in small group situations.
Techniques for studying the patterns of relationships between social entities.
A field and a set of techniques for studying networks of relations between social actors.
The extent to which for a given coding scheme two or more coders independently agree on the coding of some content.
An experiment conducted in a natural setting as opposed to a laboratory.

There is no standard definition of this term but it usually refers to the contemporaneous notes researchers make in the field based on their observations, conversations with informants, and which can include maps, rough diagrams and so on.
A set of ideas associated with a particular social group that articulates their interests and view of the world.
In a contingency table the counts or frequencies expected to be found in the table for a set of given table marginals if the variables were independent of one another.
The actual data observed in a frequency table or crosstabulation.
An approach to ethnographic research which utilises information and communication technologies to study online activities, especially in relation to consumer decision-making.
In statistics, estimation is the process of inferring the true value of a variable in the population from a sample that has been drawn from that population.
A statistical test used to assess the assumption of homogeneity in the variances of the population distributions from which different samples are drawn.
The assumption in analysis of variance that the variance of one variable is stable across the levels of another variable.

Although there is some disagreement about the term, feminist research is an approach to social research in which topics are chosen and methods used in ways that challenge methodologies developed by men, and with the aim of enhancing the position of women in society.
A field of post-structuralism that studies sexuality, gender identity and LGBT history.
In meta-analysis, a simple tally of the extent to which the various research reports being considered support or fail to support the hypothesis being studied.
Procedures for describing quantitative data through the use of summarising, organising, and graphical techniques.
The analysis of the statistical characteristics of a single variable, such as its distribution, central tendency, and spread.
A measurement or scale in which any two adjoining values are the same distance apart and in which there is a true zero point.
A measurement scale in which there is an order to the categories but no real unit of measurement.
An interval scale is a measure in which the adjacent intervals between the points of the scale are of equal extent and where the measure does not have an absolute zero point.
A classification of measurement which distinguishes between four types of scale, nominal, ordinal, interval, and ratio, which differ in terms of their mathematical complexity.
A measurement scale having categories that have no order or value and in which numbers are used as labels for the categories.

A school of philosophy associated with the German philosopher Edmund Husserl, the term phenomenology refers to the descriptive study of how things appear to consciousness, often with the purpose of identifying the essential structures that characterise experience of the world.

Associated with the phenomenological tradition, intentionality does not refer to intentions in the everyday sense of doing something for a purpose. Instead, the term signifies a state of engagement with the world, the sense that consciousness is always about something.
Statistical methods for formally contrasting and combining results from different studies in the hope of identifying patterns or other interesting relationships among study results.
Secondary analysis is the analysis of data originally collected and analysed for another purpose
Writing up or presenting your research project or findings, in the form of a thesis, dissertation, journal article, research report, conference paper or poster.

Induction is a process of reasoning that moves from particular instances to conclusions about general principles. Analytic induction is an approach to qualitative data analysis in which the search for negative instances is recurrently used to refine successive working hypotheses until all instances of a phenomenon found in the data have been satisfactorily explained.
A hypothesis is a reasoned, provisional statement capable of being empirically tested. In quantitative research such statements often concern the possible relationship between two or more variables.
A kind of reasoning developed by the philosopher Charles Sanders Peirce in which an observation or a case is related to a theory by means of plausible interpretation.
A term usually used in qualitative research to refer to research designs in which the researcher makes changes to research plans and strategies as the study unfolds.
Any of a number of qualitative research approaches influenced by phenomenological philosophy that aim to understand how people make sense of their everyday life.
In qualitative research the use of a variety of techniques for exploring the contents of documents in order to exlore the meaning and significance of particular ideas within them.

An approach focused on the identification and description of the methods and techniques that people use to produce and interpret social interaction, and which often involves detailed study of social practices such as greetings, giving directions or telling stories within a variety of formal or informal contexts.
An approach influenced by phenomenology and by hermeneutics which focuses on the detailed examination of individual lived experience and ways in which individuals make sense of that experience.
A statistical test used to compare the cumulative distribution of sample data against an expected population distribution or against the empirical distribution function of an other variable.
The process of establishing through empirical research how far a specific programme established by government or administrative bodies has achieved its goals.
A research design directed at establishing the how far a given policy, programme or intervention can be said to work.
A branch of ethnographic research which uses visual aspects of culture as ways of capturing and expressing perceptions and social realities of people.
The location, evaluation, interpretation and analysis of material found in archives.

A field research method used primarily in pre-testing survey instruments which allows researchers to collect verbal information regarding survey responses and is used to evaluate whether the question is measuring what the researcher intends.

In survey research a set of questions and their corresponding response categories produced in printed or increasingly electronic form and used with or without the presence of an interviewer as a means of collecting structured data from respondents.
In survey research, trial interviews conducted before the main phase of a survey in order to assess whether or not they work as intended.
A mixed effects model is a statistical model containing both fixed effects and random effects.
A measure of association used when each variable is measured at the ordinal level and where both variables are taken from a continuous bivariate distribution.
A judgement relating to the extent to which a measure appears "on the face of it" to be measuring what it is supposed to measure.
Autobiography refers to a literary work where the subject of the study writes their own life's account.
Interpretive repertoires can be thought of as sets of interconnected arguments, explanations, evaluations and descriptions frequently based on familiar anecdotes, illustrations, themes or clichŽs.
The skill of putting into writing and spreading the information produced from your research.

Said of sets, or groups of variables, in which the extent of membership in the set is not precise. Since a set is a clearly defined group, a fuzzy set is a group the definition of which is allowed to vary or which can be hard to operationalize.
Graphical methods of depicting the degree of association in cross tabulations.
A method based on Boolean algebra which provides a way of analysing patterns of causation in a small to moderate number of cases.
A term sometimes used to refer to nominal-level or categorical data.
The degree of scatter or variability in a set of observations.
Information gathered from the same individuals or units at several different points in time

In experimental research the choice of a small selection of different levels of an experimental treatment from a wider range of possible levels. In statistics an analytic approach based on the assumption that explanatory variables are non random.
An approach to the reading of a text that emphasises the analytic interpretation of how the elements of the text are juxtaposed in ways that give meaning to the text as a whole.
An approach to research that starts from the premise that knowledge derives from sense experience, and which usually relies heavily on observation or experiment.
Constructing a description of the nature of the proposed research, its significance and how it will be conducted.
When an eligible sample member fails to respond at all or does not provide enough information for the response to be deemed usable
When a sample member responds but does not provide a usable response to a particular item or items.
The separating out of the variance in a dependent variable that is attributable to variables that are not the subject of the study.
A sample which is representative of the population from which it is drawn.
Stories told by individuals about their experiences.
A generic term referring to the various ways in which field researchers interact and associate with those they encounter in the field.
Highly detailed written accounts of how people in a social setting lead their lives, based on systematic and long-term observation of, and discussion with, those within the setting.
Internal reliability can be thought of as the degree of consistency in the responses to a set or subset of items on a particular measure.
Convergent validity refers to the extent to which a measure is related to other measures designed to assess the same construct.

A logical calculus originally developed by the mathematician George Boole which provides an algebra for the handling of sets. The operations of conjunction, disjunction and negation in Boolean logic are equivalent to the numerical operations of multiplication, addition, and negation. In computer applications, the Boolean operators AND, OR, NOT provide ways of combining search terms.
In the analysis of panel data, a model that makes an assumption of independence between certain kinds of error term and measured variables.
The analysis of complex documentary accounts.
Monetary support for research through internal or external sources.
The regression of one variable on another.
A Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (brand of computer software), that performs most standard statistical analyses of data.
A statistics and graphics software package.
The set of rules and symbols in computer language.

A Rasch measurement model is an example of additive, conjoint, fundamental measurement by which one can create linear, objective measures applicable to the human sciences (such as in, but not limited to, education, psychology, medicine and health, marketing and business, and judging in sports).
Semiotics is the the theory of signs and the study of systems of signification and communication.
The field of moral philosophy dealing with the standards by which behaviour should be regulated within research.
Broadly speaking, honesty and probity in conducting research. The term can also refer to the extent to which data can be regarded as trustworthy.

The principle that information gathered from or about research participants in the course of a study is private and should only be revealed to third parties with the explicit consent of the individuals from whom the information was obtained.

A data archive is resource centre that acquires, stores and disseminates digital data which is then provides for secondary analysis by researchers other than the original depositor(s), and for teaching purposes.

The examination, interpretation and critique of both the material content of the channels of media of communication and the structure, composition and operations of corporations that either own or control those media.
Cross-cultural research can be defined in an anthropological sense to mean any kind of description or comparison of different cultures.

A philosophical tradition associated with figures such as Charles Pierce, William James, and John Dewey which emphasizes the linking of theory and practice. Pragmatism was important to the development of the Chicago School of Sociology, and has provided the epistemological background to a variety of qualitative methodologies.
A research design in which each of the units of analysis in a study is measured on some variable before and after an intervention.
The systematic collection, analysis and interpretation of data relating to an organisation or organisations.
A research instrument allowing the observation and recording patterns of behaviour and interaction to be made in a systematic and structured way.
The arithmetic average of the values in a population distribution.
An examination of the theory of knowledge, from a feminist standpoint.
Nonprobability sampling refers to procedures in which researchers select their sample elements not based on a predetermined probability.
The study of variables in human populations (such as births, deaths, health, fertility, and migration) and of the variables that cause them to change.
A theory of knowledge that disallows the existence of an external objective reality independent of an individual from which knowledge may be collected or gained.
A range of methods, procedures and approaches for producing and interpreting stories or narratives of people's lives.
A measure of how 'peaked' a distribution is and which therefore gives an indication of how far the distribution departs from the normal curve.
Ecological validity refers to the extent to which something studied in one environment such as a laboratory setting can be generalised to a range of other, typically 'real world', environments.

An interviewing methodology influenced by both sociological and psychoanalytic understandings of biography. The method is used to produce and analyse biographic narratives using a sequential approach to elicitation of a person's life story, and an iterative approach to analysis.
A logic applied to sets the boundaries of which are blurry. In fuzzy logic variables have a truth value that ranges between 0, absolutely false, and 1, absolutely true.

Triangulation involves the attempt to combine multiple methods, measures, methodologies or theories in a variety of ways often to cross-check finding, often on the assumption that the weaknesses of any single such element will be compensated by the strengths of others.

The exploration of physical and spatial features of a particular environment which are associated with certain social outcomes, such as social exclusion or crime, and are therefore seen as having a contributory or perhaps causal effect on social processes or social phenomena.
Generic computer-based facilities comprising hardware and software that process spatial data into digital information concerning, and used to make decisions about, a particular geographical location
A resampling approximation technique, usually computer based, used to simulate social or physical systems.
Refers to a state of mind where one intentionally turns one's awareness onto the internal and external experiences of the present moment.
A test in which the test statistic has an F-distribution under the null hypothesis.
A form of rating scale that is designed to identify the connotative meaning of objects, words, and concepts.
A series of questions designed to measure the strength of attitudes and beliefs.
A scale in which multiple items are combined in order to in order to produce a single measure of some underlying construct.
In game theory, the Nash equilibrium is defined as a conceptual solution to analyze strategic interactions and the strategic options for each game player.

Broadly speaking, the study of research methods extending from broad issues relating to epistemology, through the theoretical principles underpinning particular methods, to specific procedures for conducting research. Sometimes (incorrectly) used interchangeably with terms such as research methods or research design.
A diagram showing the values of a variable or showing a relationship between two variables. For examples see bar graph, curvilinear relation, histogram, frequency polygon, and scatterplot.
The effect on some variable of a context in which it appears.
Using survey data to provide suitable statistics for a small domain or area, typically a sub-population, that are not in themselves large enough to produce an estimate with reliable precision.
Techniques used in meta-analysis to compare the amount of heterogeneity in the significance levels and effect sizes of the studies being analysed.

The general linear model is a basic framework underlying many statistical analyses. It is often expressed in a regression-type formula in which the expected value of a random dependent variable is given as a function of a set of independent variables.

A statement that sets out standards for the proper conduct of members of some group. In the social sciences such codes are usually established by professional bodies and associations as a way of ensuring ethical conduct by members when they conduct research.

A process of research governance which seeks to ensure that research projects meet ethical standards. Typically the details of a proposed study are presented for scrutiny and acceptance by a committee set up to make sure standards are met.
A continuous variable is one within whose range of values any value is possible.
The number of values free to vary when computing a statistic.
A sampling method in which every element in the population has a known probability of being included in the sample.
The selection of sample members from a larger population such that every member of the sample has an equal chance of selection.
Broadly speaking, a process of representing the properties or behaviour of a system by means of another system. Often this simulation is carried out through the use of a computer program.
A proxy variable is a variable that is used to measure an unobservable quantity of interest, for example measuring intelligence through years of education.

A term used refer to the shared meanings that arise out social interaction or to the overall realm of subjective meaning. Sometimes the term refers to the degree of agreement between people in relation to some situation.
Judgments used to ground various approaches to research; Two examples of types of reasoning are inductive and deductive.
Data sets so large or complex that traditional data processing tools are inadequate.

A bar graph for variables measured at the interval and ratio levels. Because the data in a histogram are interval or ratio, the bars should touch; in a bar graph showing nominal or ordinal data, they should not.

A graphical display, similar to a histogram, which presents a distribution as an ordered set of observations set out so that the 'stem' showing grouped values appears to the left of a vertical line and the 'leaves' showing individual observations to the right. Its advantage is that it allows the shape of the distribution to be seen easily.
A way of depicting frequency distributions for categorical variables.

A graphical display for showing information about a distribution in a convenient and intuitive way. Looking like a box with thin lines projecting above and below it, the plot allows one quickly to identify the distribution's minimum, maximum, median, and upper and lower quartiles.
A circle with areas (“slices”) marked to represent the proportion of total units in each category.
A two-dimensional graphical representation that shows the relationship between two variables with each pair of observations plotted as a point.
Conducting studies involving participants who are below the age of 18 years.
An estimate of how a sample statistic is expected to differ from a population parameter in a random sample drawn from the population.
The average or most typical value in a distribution. The most common measures of central tendency are the mean, the median, and the mode.

A term associated with the Austrian philosopher and sociologist Alfred Schutz and which refers to those finite provinces of meaning in which one turns away from everyday life to enter another realm such as the dream world.
One of a number of Computer Assisted Qualitative Data Analysis Software (CAQDAS) programs designed to facilitate the management and analysis of qualitative data.

A software package for qualitative researchers which provides a range of tools for handling data, ideas, information and theories built up from observations, interviews, document analysis, literature reviews and other qualitative research processes.
The distribution of all possible outcomes of an event.
The study of health problems in a population, especially infectious disease.
A term occasionally used for an independent variable, so called because independent variables are controlled by experimenters.
The conceptual and analytic methods associated with the understanding of how far policies set by government or public bodies achieve their goals.
Public opinion research involves the conceptualization and measurement of what people think or how they behave.
The study of how long subjects persist, or survive, in a state. Survival analysis is a variety of event history analysis in which there are a limited number of states or conditions.
An approach that involves studying over time the movement of research participants through successive states or conditions.
A hazard rate, also known as a hazard function or hazard ratio, refers to a measure of the risk of an event occurring over a particular time period.

A term associated with the American sociologist Erving Goffman, impression management refers to the way in which individuals attempt to maintain through interactional strategies of various kinds a positive image of themselves in the eyes of others.
Those things in the environment being capable of being affecting some entity.
A rather general term that refers to research based solely or primarily on documentary sources as opposed to data produced by other means.
The tendency to respond to questions in a socially acceptable manner.
The use of software packages to aid the management and analysis of qualitative data such as interview transcripts and fieldnotes.
A test for whether the means of several groups are equal in which there is only one factor or independent variable.
A statistical test to determine if the mean ranks of three or more related samples differ significantly.
Using a set of digital tools and techniques to extract and analyse data from social media channels and the online sphere.
In conversation-analysis, turn-taking is regarded as a fundamental feature of conversation and refers to the processes by which turns are taken in conversation.
In game theory a form of representation that abstracts the interactive conditions defining a game. In computing, a programming method used for storing matrices.

A method based on the use of diaries which have been created for the purposes of research. Diaries can extend from structured instruments used in time use surveys through semi-structured reports on key events or experiences, to unstructured written accounts
A term with several meaning but generally a statement setting out procedures relevant to a particular aspect of data collection or analysis.
Showcasing your findings from a research project in written or oral form.
In statistical hypothesis testing failing to reject a null hypothesis that is in fact false.
Can refer to one of a set of procedures applied to datasets so as to protect the confidentiality of survey respondents. Also refers to the synthesising of evidence in a systematic review.
Research where young people lead in formulating the research problem, designing the study, collecting and/or analysing the data.
Research methodologies which involve active engagement between researchers and researched OR research which involves the collaboration of two or more researchers.
A term with a variety of meanings in different fields. Usually taken to refer to the concept or object to which a term refers.
The process of repeatedly taking samples from a sample to estimate what other samples from a population would look like were they available.
MAXQDA is a computer-assisted data analysis software program that facilitates the coding and analysis process.
In cluster analysis methods for producing nested clusters by joining together objects that are close to one another in terms of similarity.

In general the processes involved in rendering meaning from one language into another while attempting to retain the sense of the original. In survey research the attempt to retain the standardised meaning of survey questions when a questionnaire is translated. In Actor Network Theory translation refers to a process by which networks come to be developed.
This term can refer to how men and women differ on a wide range of social variables, but it can also refer to the way in which gender shapes fieldwork roles and relationships.
A measure of spread in a distribution given by the mean of the squared deviations from the mean.
Intensive open-ended individual interviews which deeply explore the respondent's point of view, feelings and perspectives.
A predictive method for obtaining consensus among a group of experts often used as a means of problem solving, decision making and/or forecasting.

A version of hermeneutics, also known as depth hermeneutics, sceptical of given meanings and interpretations, committed to societal transformation and individual emancipation, and concerned with conditions and practices that shape human beings as knowers and social agents.

Research participants who, by virtue of some psychological, cognitive, physical, medical, legal, socioeconomic, or age-related status, are deemed to be more susceptible to harm within the research process. They often require special protections within the research process.
Data deriving directly from observation, experimention, or elicitation.
The process of establishing through empirical research how far specific policies set by government or public bodies have achieved their goals.
Standards setting out the attributes judged to be characteristic of good research.
In structural equation modelling a directly measured variable rather than one that acts as an indicator to a latent variable.
A cross-case analysis is one that examines themes, similarities,and differences across cases where a case is regarded as any bounded unit, such as an individual, group, organization, or setting.
In social research an overall posture based on doubt about the validity of claims not supported by evidence.
The joint probability function of the sample, given the probability distributions assumed for the errors.
A test statistic for measures of association that relate two nominal variables.

In case study research the choice of one particular case for study because it is judged on theoretical, analytical, or methodological grounds to be particularly fruitful for understanding a particular phenomenon or situation.
The inner state of the self constituted by thinking, experience, emotion, belief, intentionality, self-awareness and the awareness of others.
The realm that emerges out of social interaction but which is not reducible to individual intentions.

Self-evidently, research on a large scale. As projects scale in size and complexity they often give rise to practical, intellectual, logistical, and political challenges not always found in projects of more modest size.
The act of demonstrating and explaining the research process with an emphasis on the tools and techniques available to conduct research studies.

A research design in which subjects are matched on characteristics that might affect their reaction to a treatment with one member of the pair being randomly assigned to the experimental group and the other member of the pair being assigned to the control group.
A concept popularised by the philosopher Karl Popper, falsificationism refers to the idea that theories can only "falsified", that is refuted, they can never be confirmed.

In psychology, an approach emphasising the need to attend to local moral orders and the local distribution of rights and duties as a way of understanding how different kinds of acts determine the way episodes unfold.
National census or survey data of the population collected by government agencies.
Methods for undertaking a linear transformation of a large set of correlated variables into smaller uncorrelated groups of variables.
A variable that distinguishes among subjects by sorting them into a limited number of categories, indicating type or kind.

The progressive loss of data over the course of a study. For example, in longitudinal studies initially recruited research participants might, for various reasons, not participate in later phases of a study. Since those who leave a study often differ in their characteristics from those who remain, attrition is often a source of bias.
The basic entities being studied.

A term coined by the sociologist Anthony Giddens, who argues that the social sciences are characterised and distinguished from the natural sciences by their study of phenomena that unlike the objects studied in natural science are already constituted as meaningful.
The use of an audio-recording device to capture sounds such as interview speech. The use of magnetic tape for audio capture has increasingly given way to the use of digital recording.
Influences on the responses given during an interview that can be attributed to the characteristics of the interviewer.
Developed by the American psychologist Clyde Coombs, a method for measuring preferences towards something that does not require assumptions about the underlying consistency of the preferences.
Sampling bias occurs when some elements in a population are over- or underrepresented in a sample.
The notion that language and action are indexical in the sense that their meaning depends on the context in which they arise.

Also known as a contingency table. A table showing two (or more) variables, with the categories of one variable distributed across the rows of the table, while the other variable is distributed down the columns. The number (or percentages) of cases for each combination of categories appear in the 'cells' formed by the intersection of rows and columns.

Also known as a crosstabulation. A table showing two (or more) variables, with the categories of one variable distributed across the rows of the table, while the other variable is distributed down the columns. The number (or percentages) of cases for each combination of categories appear in the 'cells' formed by the intersection of rows and columns.
In factor analysis factors that are obtained from factor-analysing the results of an oblique factor rotation (one that allows the factors to correlate).
A method that seeks to reveal the diversity of subjective opinion through the collection, selection and sorting of a range of opinions on some topic.
Using computer simulated models to study behaviour through adjusting particular variables and observing how these changes affect the outcomes.
An ordinal variable with the additional property that the magnitudes of the differences between two values are meaningful.
Variables on a linear scale wherein the intervals between the values of the interval variable are equally spaced.
Usually refers to a state of shared agreement within some social collectivity, such as a society, a group, a pool of experts, and so on.
That which people are experiencing or have experienced as a result of their awareness of living in the world.
A visual research method in which the creation of collages is used as a means to knowledge and insight into some subjective experience.

A measurement model that describes the relationship between the probability of a particular score on an item (e.g., correct/incorrect, rating on an ordered scale) and the latent variable or the latent trait that explains this score.

A metric variable is a variable measured quantitatively. The distance between the values is equal. INTERVAL, RATIO, and CONTINUOUS variables can have metric measurement and be treated as metric variables.
An interview with someone at the top of a status hierarchy in a particular field, e.g. Nobel Prize winners, but often refers to interviews with members of a political elite.
A categorical variable that can place subjects or cases into only two groups, such as alive/dead, or pass/fail.
A form of ethnography used to explore how audiences produce meaning from media discourses such as television news.
A term used in factor analysis for the proportion of the total variance in a set of measured variables that is shared by two or more factors.
A term associated with grounded theory, theoretical saturation refers the analytic phase in qualitative research in which no new data emerges to challenge the existing conceptualisation of the data.
Measures of the extent to which particular items are close or far away from each other on some metric.

A strategy for organising and summarising the findings of existing studies in order to generate new knowledge. In statistical meta-analysis the aim is to create research generalisations. Where qualitative studies are synthesised the aim is generally theory-development.
An analytic approach in qualitative research in which an analyst identifies for later retrieval the themes that emerge out of data such as interview transcripts and fieldnotes.
Internal validity refers to the confidence with which researchers can make causal inferences from the results of a particular empirical study.
A Poisson regression is a regression model in which a dependent variable that consists of counts is modelled with a Poisson distribution, a distribution appropriate to such data.
How meaning is created between people as they utilize discursive resources in imaginative and improvisational ways.
The process of assigning to participants to various experimental conditions such that each participant has an equal chance of being allocated to any condition.
A method of survey sampling which selects participants by organising them first into groups defined by characteristics, selecting a number of groups and studying all members of these groups.

In social science research the process of systematically recording and analysing one's own psychological and emotional reactions to people, objects and events in relation to particular situations or practices.
A variable that is measured using an ordinal scale, such as the shirt sizes small, medium, large, and extra large.
A statement about what will be observed before the actual event, often based on data.
The term conditional probability refers the likelihood of a particular event taking place given the occurrence of a particular previous event.

A form of participatory qualitative research in which the relationship between researchers and research participants is bilateral, with those involved working together as coresearchers and coparticipants in the design, management, and production of findings from the research. Sometimes characterized as research with people rather than on people.
The Mann-Whitney U test is a non-parametric statistical test for the significance between two dependent samples.
Research that seeks to empower those being studied
Safe fieldwork is fieldwork in which the researcher is aware of possible threats to their safety and takes steps to minimize risk.

A data analysis software designed for statistical computing and graphics, providing techniques and tools to help with linear and nonlinear modelling, classical statistical tests, time-series analysis, classification and clustering.
Factorial design is used to understand the effect of several independent variables on a single dependent variable.

An experimental approach from biomedical research used to examine how effective or efficacious some proposed treatment or intervention is likely to be. In a randomised control trial (RCT) research subjects are randomly allocated to two or more groups that differ in their exposure to the treatment or intervention.
In research, replication is the re-analysis of a study. Replication is only possible when all information about data gathering and data analysis is available.
Computer-assisted methods of information retrieval by extracting and organising knowledge from unstructured text.
Probability distribution is the various outcomes of an experiment and the probability of their occurrence.

The putting of cases or variables from several data files into one file. It is possible to combine data in various ways, e.g. by adding new variables to the dataset, adding summary data to individual-level data, and merging cases from several files.
Central limit theorem states that the larger the sample size, the more the sampling distribution approaches the normal distribution.
Polling, or opinion polling, refers to the process of surveying public opinion from a particular sample.
A Pareto chart is a bar chart where frequency values are listed in descending order.
Research conducted by professionals who themselves deliver services in organisations of some kind rather than by an outside academic evaluator.
In statistics, the range is the difference between the highest and lowest values of a variable.
A statistical test for comparing the difference between two means often used for hypothesis testing on small samples.
A group of methods designed to assess the reliability, validity, and difficulty of items on tests.
