A variable that distinguishes among subjects by sorting them into a limited number of categories, indicating type or kind. Another term for a categorical variable.
In regression analysis the rule that the line of best fit is found where the sum of the squared residuals is minimised.
A graphical representation of the causal relationships in a path model.
A systematic means of determining a person's ability in a particular skill or field of knowledge.
The Kruskal-Wallist test is a non-parametric statistical test for analyzing variance between more than two independent samples.
Psychological tests containing lists of items designed to assess the extent to which a respondent possesses personality traits of interest to the researcher.
The paired t-test is a statistical test for comparing correlated samples, pretest and posttest.

A term coined by the American sociologist Herbert Blumer, a sensitising concept is one that directs a researcher's attention towards interesting facets of what is to be studied, relevant empirical evidence, and fruitful lines of inquiy.
The Wilcoxon test is a non-parametric statistical test for significance across independent, correlated samples.

A group of scholars originally based in the inter-war period at the Institute for Social Research at the University of Frankfurt am Main, many of whose members eventually fled to the United States. Drawing not only on Marx but on Freud, and the phenomenologists, Frankfurt School theorists have been influential in the development of critical theory.
Where research is printed or published digitally to disseminate the findings.

An application of computer simulation to the social sciences useful for studying the complexity of social systems. Agents are software objects programmed to have autonomy and goals, and to act and react towards their environment and other agents within it. Running the simulation allows emerging patterns of activity to be observed and compared against those found in the real-world.
Research impact is the demonstrable contribution, change or benefit to the economy, society, culture, public policy or services, health, the environment or quality of life, beyond academia.
A study conducted at a particular moment in time that examines a cross-section of the population.
Broadly speaking, historiography can be thought of as the study of the methodology of history as a discipline. The term can also refer to how the history of a particular topic is written.

In ethnographic fieldwork the practices associated with recording events, speech, etc understood, not as a mechanical act, but as processes of selective attention and engagement in fieldwork activity.
The persuasive character of discourse.
Studies which follow particular cohorts, for example a set of people born in a particular year.
The power to which base e must be raised to produce a specific number
Any test that is designed to measure student learning in the context of an educational or training program can be called an achievement test.
Latent class analysis is a technique for analyzing relationships in categorical data; that is, relationships among variables scored at either the nominal or ordinal level of measurement.
The study of economic theory and the application of economic principles using mathematics or statistics.
The process of subjecting a theory to empirical scrutiny.
The major paradigms or ways of making knowledge claims about the social world, such as positivism and interpretivism.
A model combining both parametric and nonparametric elements
A variable in a path analysis assumed to be explained by two or more other variables in the analysis.
Multiple methods research involves more than one method being used in study.
A variable in a path analysis which explains one or more other variables but which is not itself explained by any other variable.
A telephone survey is a survey for which data is collected via the telephone.

A German word meaning "understanding", a term with a somewhat wider meaning than its English equivalent. Broadly speaking, interpretive approaches to social research see understanding to be both the aim of the social sciences and its method.
The assumption in an analysis of covariance that there is no interaction between the covariates and the independent variables.

Critical Resistance Analysis (CRA) is a narrative analysis strategy whose aim is to bring forward the kinds of subjects participants draw on when talking about themselves in narrative interviews and to make explicit how those subjects are resisted and desired.
Presenting data in an visual form (such as a graph, picture or graphics) to showcase and communicate the findings of the research.
A test of sampling adequacy used to assess how far it might be appropriate to proceed with a factor analysis.
A statistical procedure used to test the null hypothesis that variances are the same across different groups.
In time-series data, a short-term, back-and-forth movement unrelated to long-term trends.
Photovoice is a participatory research method where participants capture and discuss their reality through photographs.
The extent to which a research finding produced in a particular context is capable of being applied in a different context.
In statistics, mediation refers to where a third variable holds a relationship to both the independent variable and dependent variable.

In the grounded theory approach developed by Anselm Strauss and Juliet Corbin, the procedures by which the categories generated through an initial process of 'open coding' are refined and reduced. Feeding off and back into open coding, axial coding serves to identify the dimensions of properties, make linkages between categories, and discard what is not supported by the data.
In statistics, moderation is where the relationship between the independent variable and the dependent variable is contingent upon a third variable.
A specific rule governing a particular area of life or, more generally, the supervision and control of that area.
Realist synthesis is a method for evaluating the evidence of interventions to inform policy decisions.
The standardized difference between two sets of fitted values; used to identify influential observations.
Post-hoc analysis is the analysis of data resulting from an experiment to test for any associations that were not expected.
Predicting future events or trends on the basis of past information about them.
Data sharing refers to the process of making data available for other researchers to use.
A document detailing and summarising the findings of a research study.
Insider action research is when action research is carried out by a researcher within their own organization or community.
Stakeholders are people having a stake or a vested interest in a program, policy, project, outcome, or topic being evaluated.
Commonly used in education, design-based research is where interventions are conducted iteratively in natural settings.
A method for checking the reliability of an measure by seeing how far the scores on half of the items correlate with the scores on the other half.
Robust regression refers to a variety of techniques used in regression analysis to reduce the effect of outliers. An alternative to least squares regression.

A case which disconfirms a hypothesis. In many forms of qualitative research, negative cases are actively sought since they allow an analyst to develop an explanation capable of explaining all or most of the cases under consideration.
Process evaluation is the evaluation of how a program was implemented.
The extent to which a research account is believable, trustworthy and appropriate, with particular reference to the level of agreement between participants and the researcher.
A gatekeeper is an individual who controls access to research participants.

The basis proposition encapsulating an intellectual position Also, a document, often also referred to as a dissertation, presenting research findings offered in support of candidature for a higher academic qualification.
Access refers to researchers being able to gain entry to the population or sample that they wish to research.
Articles that appear in scholarly journals subsequent to peer-review and which are intended for the purpose e.g. of reporting research results or advancing arguments.
The process by which the researcher identifies and invites potential participants to take part in their research project.
A term used to refer to situations in which researchers convey to research participants in subtle or unconscious ways the results or patterns the researcher would prefer to see.
Total survey error is the sum of all of the errors that may result when designing and carrying out a survey.

The process of deciding on the format of questions in instruments such as questionnaires and interview schedules, in particular the decision about how far questions are to be tightly or loosely structured.
Concept mapping is a visual representation of the relationship between ideas generated by an individual or group.
Statements that claim to be true by virtue of an appeal to some grounds.
Sequential design refers to research in which stages are carried out one after the other, or, in sequence.
A variable that varies in ways the researcher does not control. For example, age is a random variable if we simply select people regardless of what age they are.
The interquartile range is the difference between the first and third quartile in a dataset. It can be used to determine outliers.
A measure of the linear association between two ordinal variables.
The semi-interquartile range is half of the interquartile range, or the difference between the first and third quartiles divided by two.
A statistical measure named after the statistician Karl Pearson, the coefficient measures the strength of the relationship between two interval or ratio variables. It varies between +1 and -1.
The z-score, or standard score, is found by subtracting the mean from a variable and dividing by the standard deviation.
Someone recognised as capable of providing authoritative knowledge and judgement within some particular domain.
The coefficient variation is the standard deviation divided by the mean. It allows comparison of variation between samples.
Typically, an arrangement of related categories into which data elements are to be classified.
Chebyshev's theorem is a rule for describing the distribution of data around the mean for all datasets.
Approaches to analysis which rely on developing a formal mathematical representation of the relationship(s) between a set of variables.
The transformative paradigm considers reality and knowledge from the perspective of marginalized groups.
A question-response format in which respondents are asked to choose from a list the response or responses most appropriate in their particular cases.
The propensity score is the probability of an individual being assigned to a test group rather than a control group in an intervention study.
A set of instructions carried out in a specified order to accomplish the completion of a specific task.
Propensity score matching is used to estimate the effect of an intervention.
Refers to a variety of methods used in the meta-analysis of research findings to calculate data not reported in the original studies.

Broadly defined, auditing is a procedure in which an independent third party systematically examines the evidence of adherence of some practice to a set of norms or standards for that practice and issues a professional opinion about the extent of that adherence.
A term referring to images of various kinds whether produced by a researcher as part of the study of society and culture, or pre-existing in the world.
A philosophical view which sees the aim of science as the development of explanations that take the form of general laws.
A test for the equality of group means used in multivariate analysis.
A correlation between two variables after the effect of one or more other variables have been held constant.

An early form of attitude scale developed by Lewis Thurstone in the 1920s. Research subjects are presented with a set of statements about a particular topic and asked to indicate their agreement with each. The statements have a numerical value which allows a mean score to be calculated.

A graphic method used in meta-analysis to detect publication bias. In the absence of publication bias a plot of sample sizes against effect sizes for the studies under consideration should be roughly funnel-shaped.
The use of multiple equations in regression where what is being modelled is too complex to allow the use of a single equation.
A variable that could have an effect on a dependent variable but which is of little interest to the researcher.

A term coined by the anthropologists George Marcus and Michael Fischer to refer to the challenge posed to traditional understandings of the social sciences as generalising frameworks by the claim that no interpretive account can adequately represent lived experience.

The assurance given to research participants that their identities will be protected from disclosure. Also refers to situations, such as in survey research, where identifying information is removed from data records.

(Also referred to as CATI.) A mode of data collection on surveys in which a computer system is used to select and contact respondents who are then interviewed over the telephone with their responses being entered into the computer.
A set of models for estimating parameters sometimes used in time series analysis.
A branch of mathematics particularly relevant to the social sciences to the study of social networks.
A concept associated with the sociologist Erving Goffman, the interaction order refers to the totality of constraint and possibility implicit in and emerging out of co-present interaction.
An international network of researchers who produce systematic reviews of the medical literature which are then made available to the public, researchers, and medical practictioners.

A correction technique used by survey researchers. It refers to statistical adjustments that are made to survey data after they have been collected in order to improve the accuracy of the survey estimates.
The extent to which the findings of a study are relevant to subjects and settings beyond those in the study.
Topics involving a level of threat risk or emotional challenge to those studied that renders problematic the collection, holding, and/or dissemination of research data.
A method of non-probability sampling in which the researcher asks someone who has already been sampled to identify others who might also participate in the research.
A measure used to establish whether the variances in two independent samples are equal.
An ordering (usually from lowest to highest) of the values of a variable and the resulting pattern of such values, often as shown for example on a graph.
A graphic representation of inequality or dispersion in a frequency distribution.
The empirical substantiation or confirmation of a claim.
A situation where an apparent correlation between two variable arises, not because one causes another, but because of the effect of a third variable.
A document presenting research findings offered in support of candidature for a, usually higher, academic qualification.

In factor analysis, a statistic indicating how much of the variation in the original group of variables is accounted for by a particular factor. It has similar uses in other forms of multivariate analysis.
An introspective method that values first person perspectives and alternative ways of knowing.
The philosophical position that physical matter is the only reality and that other sorts of phenomena, such as ideas and social values, are reducible to or are merely expressions of material reality.
In fields such as medicine, education and the like the attempt to establish what works and what doesn't through a systematic examination of the most current research in that field.
In time series analysis, when a linear combination of nonstationary variables is stationary, the variables are said to be cointegrated.
A discipline's general orientation or way of seeing its subject matter.
A survey collecting data from a sample of individuals (or groups) at a particular point in time.
A term coined by the early American sociologist Robert Park to refer to spontaneously emerging events and social processes. Examples would include crowds, riots, panics, and social movements.
The patterned social arrangements that comprise society.
An explanation of how an outcome occurs given a set of inputs.

Used in techniques such as cluster analysis and multidimensional scaling, similarity measures are quantitative expressions, usually expressed as distances, of judgements that certain entities of interest to the researcher are similar.
The principles and procedures characteristic of science and, more particularly, the natural sciences.
Broadly speaking, analytic approaches which focus on the form rather than the content of some entity.
Data, often in textual, documentary, or archival form, produced without direct intervention by a social researcher.
In exploratory data analysis, reexpression refers to ways of changing the scale upon which a variable is measured, often by taking it to some power, or taking its root or log.
The process of inferring a population value from information about a sample.

A research approach in which respondents are given ambiguous stimuli such as a picture and asked to give it a structure, on the assumption that their response will reveal something about their underlying personality. Examples would include use of the Rorschach inkblot test or the Thematic Apperception Test.
The extent to which a measure assesses the construct it is supposed to measure.

A set of principles relating to human subjects research developed by the World Medical Association and originally adopted at Helskink in 1964. The declaration has subsequently been revised on a number of occasions.

A term with a number of different meanings but one that in general refers to the importance of understanding the historically situated character of human existence. Historicism therefore treats as significant the contexts within which events and situations occur rather than explaining them by reference to general laws or universal statements.
Bringing together two or more sets of data sources.

A term associated with the anthropologist Clifford Geertz, thick description does not only imply that ethnographic description should be highly detailed but that it should attend to the circumstances, meanings, intentions, strategies, motivations, and so on that characterise a particular episode.
In its simplest terms, the depiction, portrayal, or description of social phenomena. The extent to which the social world can be represented, and in what ways, is a strongly contested issue.
Models for the analysis of covariance structures attempt to explain the relationships among a set of observed variables in terms of a generally smaller number of unobserved variables.
A statistical test developed by W. G. Cochran which is used to establish whether the frequencies of a dichotomous variable differ significantly for more than two related samples or groups.
Also known as test-retest reliability. The extent to which the results produced by a measuring instrument are stable from one use to another.

(Also referred to as CAPI.) A mode of data collection in surveys in which an interviewer conducts a face-to-face interview with a respondent, using a computer to administer the questionnaire and to record the answers.

Vignettes comprise stimuli that selectively portray elements of reality to which research participants are invited to respond and are especially valuable in exploring perceptions, attitudes, and behaviors in qualitative research.
Computer-intensive methods used for simulating large arrays of correlated observations.

Often abbreviated to BLUE, a Best Linear Unbiased Estimator is a regression line which has been computed using the least-squares criterion and where none of the assumptions are violated. It will have a smaller variance than any other estimator of the population parameter.
A tendency for subjects of research to change their behavior simply because they are being studied.
A case having an extreme value on some variable.

In grounded theory the initial phase of analysis in which the analyst is encouraged to become familiar with the data, develop some initial interpretations, and gain a sense of how to proceed further with the analysis.
Methods based on hypothetico-deductive principles.
A relationship between two or more variables that cannot be represented by a line in a two-dimensional space or a plane in a three-dimensional space.

An analytic strategy associated with the French poststructuralist philosopher Jacques Derrida based on the assumption that language has no fixed meaning. A text, therefore, is interpreted through its relationship to various contexts.
The study of complex systems in which there are very large numbers of interacting variables.
A research design in which data are collected more than once on each unit.

A wide range of philosophical doctrines and perspectives methodologically important for their belief that the mind and its ideas (not external experience) are the ultimate source and criteria of knowledge.
In content analysis counts of the number of times particular words appear in some text or texts.
In analysis of variance a factor the levels of which are drawn from a larger pool of equally usable factors.
A perspective which sees the social world and its associated meanings as routinely produced and maintained through processes of social interaction and meaning-construction.
The view that human thought and action can be judged only from the perspective of the culture out of which it has emerged.
A list of topics or themes to be covered in an interview, sometimes called a topic guide or an aide-memoire.
In network analysis, data focused on the social linkages between individuals. The term can also refer to the data held in a relational database.
Data collection skills refers to the skills that an individual requires to effectively collect and curate data for research purposes.
Data analysis skills refers to the skills that an individual requires to effectively interpret and understand data for research purposes.
Study skills refers to the skills that an individual requires to be successful in their studies.
Researcher skills refers to the skills that an individual requires to be a successful researcher.
Professional skills refers to the skills that an individual requires to be successful in the workplace.
Student success refers to the skills that an individual requires to be successful in their studies.
Career development refers to the process of acquiring the skills necessary to plan and successfully navigate a career.
Practical skills refers to skills that are acquired through practical application and can be applied directly to solve a problem or issue.
Professional communication refers to the strategies and approaches that make for effective speaking, listening and writing in the workplace.
Doing research refers to the act of carrying out research through data collection and data analysis.
Researcher development refers to the process of acquiring the skills necessary to be a successful researcher.
A scale based on the results of a factor analysis.
